Vaelle believes that the cult fanatics acted on their own, not under Lord Cassalanter's orders. She won't reveal the Cassalanters as the leaders of the cult unless magically compelled to do so.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: Proceed with encounter 10, "Converted Windmill."

entries.name: Villain Lairs
entries: Chapters 5 through 8 describe the lairs of the main villains. The characters might want to explore the lairs for a variety of reasons, including the following:

items: Disrupting the villain's operation
Gaining an audience with the villain (perhaps to forge a truce or an alliance)
Completing a special mission for a faction (see "Joining Factions,")
Investigating a false clue given to them as part of a scheme concocted by another villain
Stealing the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} if the villain has it, or finding leads on its whereabouts when the trail goes cold

entries.name: Mausoleum: Winter
entries: The {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} has revealed that the Vault of Dragons lies beneath the Brandath family mausoleum in the City of the Dead. The characters are unlikely to know it, but the Brandath family is an old one. Lord Dagult Neverember married into it for its wealth, and Lady Brandath gave birth to his son, Renaer. It's a dark irony that Neverember entrusted the location of his embezzled gold to his dead wife's family. {@creature Renaer Neverember|wdh} would be horrified but not surprised to learn the truth.

The cemetery is buried in snow, and though some visitors are drawn to its scenic beauty even in winter, the blizzard keeps most of them away. The crumbling mausoleum is sealed tight, and the name BRANDATH is etched above its entrance. Large elm and birch trees grow around the structure, sheltering it as best they can with their leafless boughs.

entries.name: Guardian Treant
entries: The largest tree growing in front of the entrance is a {@creature treant}. It awakens when one or more creatures approach the entrance and growls, "Only those of Brandath blood are welcome here! Begone!" The treant is particularly surly, it being winter and all.
If someone other than a Brandath descendant tries to open the mausoleum, the treant animates two nearby trees and then attacks. The treant and its animated allies are too big to enter the mausoleum.

The characters can kill the treant, try to slip past it, or retreat until they learn more about the Brandath family. A day's research followed by a successful DC 10 Intelligence (Investigation) check reveals that the characters know one such person: {@creature Renaer Neverember|wdh}. If they ask Renaer to admit them to the Brandath family mausoleum, he agrees to do so. Because the treant can sense that Renaer has Brandath blood in his veins, it allows him and those he calls his friends to enter unmolested, and says to Renaer in passing, "Your mother was a lovely person."

entries.name: Glyph of Warding
entries: A {@spell glyph of warding} spell has been cast on the first step leading down to the underground level, set to trigger when a humanoid creature passes over the step. The glyph can't be spotted unless the dust on the floor is cleared away by a {@spell gust of wind} spell or some other means. Once the dust is swept aside, a character who searches the stairs notices the glyph with a successful DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check.

If the glyph is triggered, it erupts with magical fire in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on it. The fire spreads around corners. Each creature in the area must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@dice 5d8}) fire damage on a failed saving throw, or half as much damage on a successful one. The glyph disappears after it is triggered.

entries.name: Uld's Resting Place
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of transmutation that emanates from one of the stone coffins on the underground level. This crypt contains the shattered bones of Uld Brandath, a Waterdavian magister who died in a freak accident decades ago. (A gargoyle broke off the corner of a government building and fell on Uld, crushing him.) Guarding his remains are six {@creature crawling claw||crawling claws} made from the hands of murderers who were sentenced to death by Uld. These undead hands spring out and attack when the lid is lifted or shoved aside.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Lying amid the bones is Uld's {@item headband of intellect}, which the characters can retrieve once the crawling claws are dealt with.

entries.name: Path to the Vault
entries: The collapsed eastern end of the underground level is actually an illusion that conceals an intact, 10-foot-wide passageway that slopes down. The characters can walk right through the illusion, which has no substance, and a {@spell dispel magic} spell destroys it. The tunnel wends downward for several hundred feet, gradually widening to 20 feet where it ends at the doors to the Vault of Dragons.

entries.name: Encounter 5: Rooftop Chase
entries: This encounter uses the chase rules in chapter 8 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|dmg}. It also uses the Rooftop Chase Complications table, which applies only to creatures moving across rooftops on foot. Flying creatures needn't roll on the table.

entries.caption: Rooftop Chase Complications
rows: You come to a 10-foot-wide gap between rooftops. You can jump over the gap if your Strength is 10 or higher (each foot you clear costs 1 foot of movement), and you must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or fall {@condition prone} on the far rooftop. Or you can cross the gap using a 10-foot-long rope line that stretches between the two rooftops

You come to a rooftop that's 10 feet higher than the one you're on. Make a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check. On a failed check, the height change counts as 10 feet of {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

You come to a rooftop that's 10 feet lower than the one you're on. Make a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check to jump down safely. On a failed check, you take damage from the fall and land {@condition prone}.
A roof is slippery. Make a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, you fall {@condition prone}.

You step on a rotten section of roof, and it collapses underneath you. Make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, you fall partway into the hole in the roof and become stuck. While stuck, you are {@condition prone} and {@condition restrained}. You can use an action on your turn to make a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check, ending the effect on a success.
Roof shingles or tiles give way as you step on them. Make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, you fall {@condition prone} and slide 10 feet back.

A rooftop protuberance such as a chimney or weather vane gets in your way. Make a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. On a failed check, the obstacle counts as 5 feet of {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

You startle a flock of birds nesting on the rooftop, and they flutter all around you. Make a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the birds count as 10 feet of {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

You trigger a {@spell glyph of warding} spell placed on the roof to discourage burglars. Make a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, you are targeted by a {@spell Tasha's hideous laughter} spell, the effect of which lasts 1 minute.

Someone on the ground throws a rock, a snowball, or a similar projectile at you. Make a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the attack deals no damage but distracts you and counts as 5 feet of {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

entries.name: Rooftop Chase: Summer
entries: The characters are trying to catch up with three {@creature spined devil||spined devils} that keep low above the rooftops, so as not to be seen by Waterdeep's Griffon Cavalry. The devils are 100 feet away from the characters at the start of the chase.
If the devil carrying the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} becomes {@condition incapacitated}, another devil snatches the stone and flees with it.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: When the characters are close to getting the stone, or when you want the chase to end, all remaining spined devils duck into an alley. If the characters lose their quarry, they can question city folk on the ground who saw where the devils went. Continue with encounter 1, "Alley."

entries.name: Rooftop Chase: Autumn
entries: The characters are chasing two {@creature drow gunslinger|WDH|drow gunslingers} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) across windy rooftops in the Dock Ward. The drow stick together as they run, but each one acts on his own initiative count.

{@creature Fel'rekt Lafeen|WDH} and {@creature Krebbyg Masq'il'yr|WDH} start out 40 feet ahead of their pursuers. They do nothing but move on their turns, trying to put as much distance between themselves and the characters as possible. Fel'rekt has the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} at the start of the chase, but one drow gunslinger can pass the stone to the other as a reaction as long as the two drow are within 10 feet of each other.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: The drow keep running across the rooftops until they get to the run-down dockside neighborhood known as Mistshore. Characters who remain in pursuit can follow them all the way there. If all the characters lose their quarry, they can question city folk on the ground who saw the drow heading toward Mistshore. In either case, proceed with encounter 2, "Mistshore."

entries.name: Rooftop Chase: Winter
entries: A Zhent named Vevette Blackwater (CE female Tethyrian human {@creature swashbuckler|VGM}; see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) has snatched the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} and is fleeing as fast as she can across icy rooftops during a blizzard. Characters who intend to pursue her are 60 feet away from their quarry at the start of the chase and must also take to the rooftops or lose sight of her.

Vevette was a vicious pirate before she joined the Zhentarim and rose to become one of {@creature Manshoon|WDH}'s favored lieutenants. She cackles madly in the face of danger and loves a good chase. She knows the streets, alleys, and rooftops of Waterdeep well. If forced to make an ability check or a saving throw because of a chase complication, she has advantage on the roll. Also, she can take the Dash action during the chase without having to make Constitution checks to avoid {@condition exhaustion}.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: The chase lasts no more than 5 rounds, after which Vevette drops to the ground and ducks into a theater. Characters who lose sight of her can ask people along her path to help them out. Continue with encounter 6, "Theater."

entries.name: Encounter 6: Theater
entries: Whether the theater is open for business or shut down, it has the following features:

items: Ceilings in the rooms are 10 feet high except in {@area P5|196}, which has a 20-foot-high raftered ceiling. Connecting the rooms are 8-foot-high passages and 7-foot-high doorways.

The theater is lit by lanterns that have {@spell continual flame} spells cast on them. Speaking a command word inside the theater causes the lights in the theater and backstage to dim; speaking another command word inside the theater restores them to full brightness. All the stage managers know the command words.

entries.name: Areas of the Theater
entries: The following locations are keyed to map 4.4.

entries.name: P1. Lobby
entries: This plush lobby is decorated with red carpet and ornate wallpaper. On display here are several painted wooden mannequins dressed in fancy costumes, each one representing a character from a famous play.

entries.name: P2. Ticket Booths
entries: The western door on each booth is locked. The lock can be picked by a character who succeeds on a DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, or the door can be forced open with a successful DC 13 Strength (Athletics) check. The ticket sellers and the stage manager have keys to these doors.
A stack of torn tickets sits on a shelf beneath a counter inside the booth. Prior to a show, each booth holds a ticket seller ({@creature commoner}). Admission to the theater is 1 sp per person.

entries.name: P3. Ticket Offices
entries: A desk near the far wall in each of these rooms contains notebooks, {@item paper (one sheet)|PHB|papers}, and a lockbox.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The house managers hold the key to each lockbox. A lock can be picked by someone who makes a successful DC 12 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, or a lockbox can be forced open with a successful DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check. During a performance, each lockbox holds {@dice 10d10} sp. After a performance, both boxes are empty.

entries.name: P4. Auditorium
entries: The auditorium has the following features:

items: Cushioned seats are arranged in seven tiered rows facing a 5-foot-high wooden stage. Each row has twenty seats.
Behind a raised red curtain are painted backdrops and stage props for the current production.

entries: During a performance, a stage manager ({@creature commoner}) watches from the back of the seating area.

entries.name: P5. Wing
entries: This small offstage area is painted black and has a table that holds fake daggers, swords, and other props. Prop weapons can be used in combat but deal only 1 bludgeoning damage on a hit.

entries.name: P6. Stage Manager's Office
entries: This room holds a desk covered in papers. The stage manager ({@creature commoner}) stays here between performances.

entries.name: P7. Green Room
entries: A trio of mismatched couches and a stained beige rug are the main features of this room, whose walls are covered with light green paint. This is where the actors congregate when they aren't on stage or in their dressing rooms.

entries.name: P8. Dressing Rooms
entries: This room contains clothes racks, tables lined with makeup, and long wall mirrors. During or immediately before a performance, each dressing room holds {@dice 1d3} actors ({@creature commoner||commoners}).

entries.name: Theater: Spring
entries: The name of the Pink Flumph theater is displayed on a sign mounted to the building's facade. Posters on the outside walls advertise the latest shows, {@i Meet the Goodberrys} and {@i Kiss of the Lamia}. The former is a comical glimpse into the travails of a large halfling family engaged in illicit criminal activity. The latter is a tragic play about an evil Mulhorandi prince who is banished to a desert, {@condition charmed} by a lamia, and sent back with powerful magic items to conquer his homeland in her name.

In the early hours of the morning, the backstage area is abuzz with halfling actors donning costumes, wigs, and makeup in preparation for the afternoon's show. As that show wraps, the cast and musicians for the evening's tragic fare arrive. The actor who plays the evil prince is a woman named Yaliek Iltizmar (N female Rashemi {@creature bard|VGM}; see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), who is also a member of the Harpers. She pays close attention to characters who nose around backstage, then shares any interesting revelations with {@creature Remallia Haventree|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) at the earliest opportunity. If Remallia learns the location of the Vault of Dragons, she sees that the information reaches the Lords of Waterdeep by conveying it to {@creature Mirt|WDH}.

entries.name: Theater Owner
entries: The owner of the Pink Flumph, Iokaste Daliano (N female Tethyrian {@creature commoner}), is a selfish, middle-aged widow with no great love of theater. The Pink Flumph was her husband's passion; for Iokaste, it's strictly a means through which she can rub shoulders with the city's elite. She requires the directors to choose plays and hire actors, while she spends her time "on the job" greeting important guests and promising them the finest entertainment. She treats her actors and staff like half-forgotten children, and she turns away characters who come to the theater seeking the Vault of Dragons unless there's something in it for her. Appealing to her greed backfires, since Iokaste wants all the treasure for herself.

entries.name: Path to the Vault
entries: One of the dressing rooms ({@area P8|199}) contains a secret trapdoor in the floor that no one knows about. It can be found with a successful DC 20 Wisdom (Perception) check. This stone door has an {@spell arcane lock} spell cast on it and can be pulled open with a successful DC 30 Strength (Athletics) check. A {@spell knock} spell or similar magic also does the trick.

Below the trapdoor is a 30-foot-deep shaft containing a wooden ladder. Characters who descend the ladder find themselves at one end of a 20-foot-wide stone passageway that gradually slopes down 100 feet before ending at the entrance to the Vault of Dragons.

entries.name: Wishes the Faerie Dragon
entries: Iokaste's late husband, Algondar Daliano, had a violet {@creature faerie dragon (violet)||faerie dragon} companion named Wishes. The faerie dragon detests Iokaste but remains on the payroll, begrudgingly using its magic to enhance performances for the sake of preserving Algondar's legacy. It prefers to remain {@condition invisible} and unseen otherwise. Iokaste refers to it derisively as "the flying serpent."

If the characters threaten it or endanger the theater, Wishes uses its magic to confound and neutralize them. As they make their way to the Vault of Dragons, it follows them invisibly. Once it learns about the gold in the vault, the faerie dragon casts {@spell mirror image} on itself, turns visible, and addresses the characters telepathically. It demands a share of the hoard (at least 5,000 gp), threatens to tip off the City Watch if the characters refuse, and makes good on its threat if the characters don't share the wealth. The faerie dragon doesn't have a hoard of its own, since it gives its earnings to unfortunate Waterdavians by invisibly flying around the city at night and leaving coins on doorsteps, window sills, nightstands, and pillows.

entries.name: Theater: Autumn
entries: At the end of their previous encounter, the characters are no closer to finding the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}. Jarlaxle is waiting for them at the Seven Masks Theater in the Dock Ward. The theater caters to a lower-class clientele, and ship captains and sailors are admitted for free. The owner of the theater is a burly and jovial Shou man with a braided goatee named Rongquan Mystere-another of Jarlaxle's many disguises. When Jarlaxle is away, he entrusts his stage managers to look after things.

entries.name: Sapphiria's Booty
entries: When the characters first arrive, all doors except the ones leading backstage are locked. Characters who slip in through the back see actors and stagehands bustling about and the director arguing with the playwright while the stage manager looks on helplessly. On the stage, actors walk through their scenes and read their lines to a mostly empty theater. Watching the rehearsal from the front row while smoking a pipe is {@creature Jarlaxle Baenre|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), disguised as Rongquan. Hidden in the shadows in various spots are four {@creature drow elite warrior||drow elite warriors} ready to fight by Jarlaxle's side.

The play, {@i Sapphiria's Booty}, is a romantic comedy about a blue-haired madam named Sapphiria who runs a thieves' guild out of a festhall. When a charming sea captain arrives with a hold full of booty from a faraway land, Sapphiria decides to steal it. Zaniness ensues when she falls in love with the first mate, who is half her age, while the captain falls in love with her. On one side of the stage is a backdrop resembling the deck of a ship; the other side is decorated to look like a madam's parlor in a brothel, complete with a gaudy chandelier and a fainting couch.

Westra Moltimmur (CG female Illuskan human {@creature commoner} with Insight +2 and Performance +6), the play's leading lady, is one of Waterdeep's great treasures, and the cast and crew are very protective of her. Now in her seventies and having been married no fewer than seven times, she has a brisk sense of humor and a zest for life. She's also insightful enough to know that "Rongquan Mystere" isn't what he appears to be. She has seen the dark elves who watch over Rongquan and observed him using subtle hand gestures (Drow Sign Language) to communicate with them.

entries.name: Speaking with Rongquan
entries: Jarlaxle has instructed the stage managers to bring all visitors to him. In the guise of Rongquan, he claims to be a member of the Lords' Alliance who answers directly to {@creature Laeral Silverhand|WDH}. He also seems to know all about the characters' meeting with Laeral (see encounter 1, "Alley") and says he can speak on her behalf. He asks about the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} and is disappointed if the characters don't have it. If they offer up the fake stone recovered in encounter 9, "Cellar Complex," Rongquan immediately realizes it's a fake.
If the characters aren't sure what to do next, Jarlaxle imparts the following information:

"My friends, don't be discouraged. The wind is blowing in our direction! I've learned that Fenerus Stormcastle was arrested by the City Watch for theft and taken to a courthouse in the Castle Ward to face the judgment of a magister. No doubt he hid the stone before his capture. You must speak to him right away. You'll need to devise some sort of ruse to get close to Fenerus. I urge against violence, or you might find yourself locked up beside him."

If the characters ask why {@creature Laeral Silverhand|WDH} doesn't question Fenerus herself or bail him out of jail, Jarlaxle laughs and says it would be politically unwise for the Open Lord to be seen negotiating with a man who has committed heinous crimes against the city.

Jarlaxle could speak to Fenerus himself, but he's not sure if the courthouse is warded against magic. He can't risk the exposure, so he sends the characters instead. If the characters refuse to work for Rongquan, he shrugs his broad shoulders and lets them leave unmolested, figuring they'll try to talk to Fenerus anyway.

If the characters attack him, Jarlaxle smiles, whistles for his drow bodyguards, and has at them. If the characters fall in combat, Jarlaxle and his guards stabilize dying party members before dragging all of them to a snowy alley and leaving them there with their gear. After the drow depart, a cold wind tears through the alley and awakens the {@condition unconscious} characters.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: If the characters decide to speak with Fenerus, proceed with encounter 8, "Courthouse."

entries.name: Theater: Winter
entries: As this encounter opens, the characters follow a fleeing Zhent swashbuckler into a theater in the Trades Ward called the Brizzenbright. Named after Malkolm Brizzenbright, its dead owner, the establishment has struggled in recent years. It stays open in the winter for its own survival, but the theater is wickedly cold this time of year.

entries.name: Brizzenbright's Ghost
entries: Malkolm Brizzenbright, a {@creature ghost}, greets all visitors in the lobby ({@area P1|191}). Dressed in a suit, his hair unkempt, he floats in plain sight most of the time, waving his hands about in gestures of greeting and salutation. Locals are accustomed to his spectral form and his stock introduction: "Let not this harried visage diminish you, gentlesirs and beautiful ladies, for I am but your friendly host. What fine art have we wrought for you this day? Buy your tickets and behold! You shan't be disappointed!"

The ghost can engage in light conversation. It is bound to the theater because Malkolm Brizzenbright's soul couldn't bear to leave the place. If the theater were to close down, the ghost would haunt it still, perhaps becoming more deranged over time. Only razing or burning the theater to the ground can force his spirit to depart forever.

entries.name: Snakes in the House
entries: After a harrowing rooftop chase, Vevette Blackwater (CE female Tethyrian human {@creature swashbuckler|VGM}; see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) has bought a ticket and slipped into the theater during a performance of {@i Blood Wedding} -a play about love, jealousy, and death. In the story, a young woman is brought to a castle by a count, only to fall in love with his younger brother, a man of faith. Her betrayal eats away at the jealous count. He murders his brother on his wedding day and pursues the bride, who hurls herself off the castle battlements in despair. The count is cursed by the gods and transformed into a creature of darkness, damned to live in his castle and feed on blood. A female cellist and two male violinists provide musical accompaniment.

The shivering audience includes thirty {@creature commoner||commoners}. Also present is a Zhentarim spy named Agorn Fuoco (NE male Turami {@creature bard|VGM}; see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) and his companion, Amath Sercent (LE female Mulan {@creature priest} of Bane). Agorn is swept up in the drama and fighting back tears while Amath pats his arm gently. Vevette takes a seat behind them and surreptitiously passes the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} to Agorn. Looking on from the back row is {@creature Remallia Haventree|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), a member of the Harpers who suspects Agorn of being a high-ranking Zhent. She has been watching him for a while now, hoping to identify other Zhentarim leaders in Waterdeep. Although Remallia appears to be alone, the two violinists (LG male Illuskan human {@creature spy||spies} with Performance +5) are Harpers under her command. Agorn and Amath are unaware that they're under surveillance.

entries.name: Enter the Heroes
entries: The characters are expected to buy tickets before entering the main theater. The house manager chases after them if they don't, threatening to summon the City Watch.

A character who makes a successful DC 14 Wisdom (Perception) check spots Vevette in the darkened theater. When this happens, Vevette springs from her chair and flees out the nearest door, planning to lead the characters on another merry chase. Remallia and her fellow Harpers watch with interest but don't get involved unless their lives or the lives of innocents are imperiled.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: If the characters take the bait, proceed with encounter 3, "Street Chase." Once Vevette's pursuers are out of sight, Agorn Fuoco and Amath Sercent use the distraction to slip away, exiting through the main doors and flagging down a hire-coach.

entries.name: Encounter 7: Old Tower
entries: The characters face enemies in a dilapidated tower built by some half-forgotten Waterdavian mage hundreds of years ago. It has the following features:

items: All doors are unlocked except the one to {@area O5|1b2}.
The rooms have 15-foot-high ceilings, with 7-foot-high doorways connecting them.
The tower is brightly lit by {@spell continual flame} spells cast on wall sconces.

entries.name: Areas of the Old Tower
entries: The following locations are keyed to map 4.5.

entries.name: O1. Vestibule
entries: The outer door has a tiny peephole with a closed iron shutter on the inside. Rotting tapestries adorn the walls, and mud and dirt have accumulated on the floor.

entries.name: O2. Ground Level
entries: Stone spiral stairs curl up into the tower and down into the cellar. Set into the west wall is a fireplace blackened with soot. A burned heap that used to be a padded leather chair lies near the fireplace.

entries.name: O3. Upper Level
entries: This room, formerly a wizard's laboratory, contains the following features:

items: A soot-stained fireplace has a lidless iron cauldron hanging on an iron hook in its hearth and a wizard's portrait on the wall above the mantelpiece.
The floor is littered with shards of broken glass, burned scraps of paper, twisted pieces of metal, and bird droppings.
Other furnishings include a rocking chair, a trellis table, and the charred remains of a bookshelf, all shrouded in thick cobwebs.
Arrow slits line the walls, and pigeons nest in the rafters.

entries.name: Arrow Slits
entries: Each arrow slit is 4 feet tall and 1 foot wide-big enough for a Small character or a slim Medium character to squeeze through.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A thorough search of the room yields a random treasure, determined by rolling a {@dice d4} and consulting the Old Tower Treasure table.

entries.caption: Old Tower Treasure Table
rows: A charred {@item wand of magic missiles} (each time a charge is expended, there's a {@chance 50|50 percent} chance that nothing happens and the charge is wasted)

A {@item potion of healing} mixed with a {@item potion of flying} (if this mixture is imbibed, roll on the {@table Variant: Mixing Potions; Potion Miscibility||Potion Miscibility} table in chapter 7 of the Dungeon Master's Guide to determine the effect)
A cracked {@item driftglobe} that emits a flickering light but otherwise functions normally
A burned scroll tube containing two blank sheets of paper that are actually {@item paper bird|wdh|paper birds} (see appendix A)

entries.name: O4. Cellar
entries: This room contains the following features:

items: A small, circular wooden table is surrounded by four stools made from empty barrels. A marked deck of playing cards is scattered atop the table, with a few stray cards lying on the floor.
Three crates are stacked against the south wall. Each contains a twenty-day supply of edible rations.
Set into the north wall is a sturdy oak door with iron fittings and a built-in lock.

entries.name: Locked Door
entries: The door to {@area O5|1b2} is locked. The lock can be picked by a character who uses thieves' tools and makes a successful DC 20 Dexterity check. The door can also be forced open with a successful DC 25 Strength (Athletics) check.

entries.name: O5. Teleportation Circle
entries: Arcane runes are inscribed in a circle on the floor of this otherwise empty chamber. The circle is a permanent teleportation circle (see the {@spell teleportation circle} spell description in the {@book Player's Handbook|phb}).

entries.name: Old Tower: Spring
entries: The party's elusive quarry, a {@creature kenku}, has taken refuge in an old tower. By the time the characters reach the entrance to the tower, the kenku has taken a hostage and fled to the upper level.

entries.name: Street Urchins
entries: Just prior to the kenku's arrival, three children entered the derelict tower on a dare. If this encounter occurs on or around Trolltide, the children are wearing troll masks. These noncombatants are named {@creature Nat|WDH}, {@creature Jenks|WDH}, and {@creature Squiddly|WDH} (see "{@area The Three Urchins|14e|x}").

The kenku has kidnapped {@creature Squiddly|WDH} and taken him upstairs ({@area O3|1ac}). The characters encounter {@creature Nat|WDH} and {@creature Jenks|WDH} in {@area O2|1ab}; they beg the characters to save their young tiefling friend.

entries.name: Confronting the Kenku
entries: The kenku clutches the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} in one clawed hand and {@creature Squiddly|WDH} the tiefling in the other. When cornered, the creature mimics the sound of a screaming child-its way of threatening to harm the boy unless the characters leave at once. The kenku doesn't respond to verbal threats or attempts at persuasion, but it can be bribed with coin, gemstones, or shiny baubles. It gives up both the stone and the boy in return for 100 gp worth of treasure.

If the characters and the kenku reach an impasse, {@creature Squiddly|WDH} kicks the kenku in the shin, causing it to release him, and hides under some old furniture. This act initiates combat as the kenku draws its sword.
If he has a clear path to the stairs, {@creature Squiddly|WDH} runs down them and rejoins his friends. The three children flee the tower together, disappearing into a nearby alley.

entries.name: Gazer Attack
entries: When the characters finally obtain the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}, three {@creature gazer|VGM|gazers} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) enter {@area O3|1ac} through the arrow slits and attack. They try to incapacitate whichever character has the stone and use their telekinetic rays to steal it. If successful, the gazers take the stone to a nearby alley.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: Whether the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} leaves the tower in the possession of the characters or the gazers, proceed with encounter 1, "Alley."

entries.name: Old Tower: Summer
entries: The old tower, formerly owned by a wizard, was recently bought by Esvele Rosznar, a young noblewoman with a fascinating alter ego (see "The {@creature Black Viper|WDH}" in appendix B).

entries.name: House Rosznar Guards
entries: Esvele has brought four {@creature guard||guards} with her to the tower. They wear the livery of House Rosznar and stand guard in {@area O1|1aa}.

entries.name: Bought and Paid For
entries: Through her network of spies, Esvele learned about Lord Neverember's friendship with the tower's previous owner. Not long thereafter, she found the entrance to the Vault of Dragons beneath the tower. Unfortunately for her, she doesn't know what keys are needed to enter it or what lies within. When the characters arrive, Esvele is in {@area O2|1ab}, meeting with the following three guild representatives ({@creature commoner||commoners}):

items: Sembra Vashir (LN female Calishite human), of the Carpenters', Roofers', and Plaisterers' Guild
Pynt Oomtrowl (CG female rock gnome), of the Cellarers' and Plumbers' Guild
Jarbokken Frostbeard (LG male shield dwarf), of the Guild of Stonecutters, Masons, Potters, and Tile-makers

entries: This meeting is a formality. As the new owner, Esvele is required by law to bring the building up to code. She is gathering cost estimates from the guilds involved but has no intention of proceeding with repairs. The arrival of the characters provides her with a welcome distraction.

Characters will have a tough time convincing Esvele that they have come for any reason other than to break into the Vault of Dragons. Esvele is willing to bring them on as business partners, allowing them access to the vault (preferably when there aren't guild representatives around) in exchange for an equal share of whatever treasure it might contain. She and the characters have each other over a barrel. She can't have them arrested for burglary without the authorities discovering the vault and seizing the tower. And they can't afford to deny the noblewoman what she wants, lest she divulge the vault's location to the authorities in exchange for a reward.

Esvele offers to help the characters obtain the keys needed to unlock the Vault of Dragons and insists on accompanying them during their first foray into the vault, claiming all the while that she's capable of looking after herself. However this business with the party unfolds, she tries to conceal her secret identity from the characters for as long as possible.
Esvele doesn't use a key to lock and unlock the door to {@area O5|1b2}. She uses thieves' tools instead.

entries.name: Path to the Vault
entries: The entrance to the vault is hidden behind a secret door in the north wall of {@area O5|1b2}. The secret door was crafted by skilled dwarf engineers and requires a successful DC 20 Wisdom (Perception) check to locate. Esvele has already disarmed a magic trap on the door, rendering it safe to open. Beyond it lies a dusty staircase that descends 90 feet to a 20-foot-wide corridor. The hall extends another 90 feet to the vault doors. To one side of the vault doors, a natural fissure in the wall once served as a grick's lair, but Esvele killed the grick and left its corpse on the floor.

entries.name: Old Tower: Autumn
entries: The characters come to this crumbling tower in the Dock Ward looking for the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}. Members of Bregan D'aerthe follow them invisibly. Superstitious locals think the tower is haunted, so they avoid it.

entries.name: Antimagic Field
entries: The interior of the tower is subject to a permanent {@spell antimagic field} spell. Consequently, no magic functions inside the tower. This effect was left behind by the tower's previous occupant, a wizard hermit who dabbled in "wild magic" and could no longer control it. Because of the antimagic field, the magic lights that normally illuminate the tower have been suppressed. Only a {@spell wish} spell or similar magic can end this antimagic effect.

entries.name: Tower Swords
entries: Scattered on the floors throughout the tower are six longswords with no traces of rust or blood on them. These blades are {@creature flying sword||flying swords} rendered inert by the antimagic field. If a flying sword is taken from the tower, it animates and attacks.

entries.name: Where's the Stone?
entries: Fenerus hid the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} in the cauldron that hangs in the fireplace on the upper level ({@area O3|1ac}). But it's not there anymore.

Before the characters reach {@area O3|1ac}, three {@creature drow gunslinger|WDH|drow gunslingers} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) under the effect of {@item potion of invisibility||potions of invisibility} use their {@spell levitate} spells to scale the outside of the tower and crawl through the arrow slits. While they are inside the tower, their {@spell invisibility} spells are negated by the antimagic field. One of the drow quickly finds the stone and takes it before the characters show up.

Unless they were defeated earlier in the adventure, these drow are Jarlaxle's lieutenants: {@creature Fel'rekt Lafeen|WDH}, {@creature Krebbyg Masq'il'yr|WDH}, and {@creature Soluun Xibrindas|wdh}. Replace any that were killed earlier in the adventure with other drow gunslingers, and roll initiative for each drow. Soluun (or his replacement) can't resist a good fight and attacks the characters, buying time for the other drow to escape. Once they're outside the tower, the fleeing drow become {@condition invisible} again as they leap onto a nearby rooftop, but the potions wear off at the end of their next turns, enabling characters to chase after them.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: If the characters pursue the fleeing drow, proceed with encounter 5, "Rooftop Chase."

entries.name: Old Tower: Winter
entries: The characters have learned that the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} is with Amath Sercent, a priest of Bane who is allied with {@creature Manshoon|WDH}. She and her acolytes reside in Yellowspire, a Castle Ward tower so named because its bricks have a pale yellow tinge to them. Amath is in the midst of converting the tower into a temple of Bane. A teleportation circle in the basement allows for swift transport to and from Kolat Towers and {@creature Manshoon|WDH}'s extradimensional sanctum.

entries.name: House of Tyranny
entries: Amath Sercent (LE female Mulan {@creature priest}) and her four followers (LE male and female {@creature acolyte||acolytes} of mixed ethnicities) dress in common clothing when outside the tower. Inside the structure, they wear fur-lined robes to stay warm. They refer to the tower as the House of Tyranny, and black prints of their right hands, with fingers and thumb held together, cover every interior surface. These handprints mimic the symbol of Bane.

Amath and her followers assemble here for worship but sleep elsewhere. When the characters first arrive, all five have gathered in prayer on the upper floor of the tower ({@area O3|1ac}). Three black {@creature flying snake||flying snakes} nest in the rafters and join any battle here. During this ceremony, Amath and her acolytes hold candles and form a circle around a gagged and blindfolded broadsheet publisher named Shan Chien (N male Shou human {@creature commoner}). The imperious, middle-aged man is shackled to the floor, and Amath carries the key to the shackles. The shackles can be broken by a creature that uses an action to make a successful DC 20 Strength (Athletics) check. Picking the shackles' lock requires thieves' tools and a successful DC 15 Dexterity check.

The Banites' ritual is designed to break Shan's will, making him subservient to Bane. Amath has been using this ritual to "turn" broadsheet publishers as part of a larger plot to control the flow of information in the city-a critical element of {@creature Manshoon|WDH}'s takeover. Shan was abducted by Amath's acolytes the night before while walking to his home in the Trades Ward. He publishes {@i The Targe}, a broadsheet that offers up vitriolic rants on all manner of local topics, including politics.
Amath has the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} in her pocket. She is expecting {@creature Manshoon|WDH} or his simulacrum to arrive and retrieve it shortly.

entries.name: Outer Scaffolding
entries: The tower is encircled by wooden scaffolding covered with ice and snow. Despite its precarious appearance, the scaffolding is secure and safe to walk on, enabling creatures to scale the outside of the tower without having to make ability checks. The scaffolding rattles and creaks, however, and any creature that moves on it must succeed on a DC 16 Dexterity (Stealth) check or be heard by the tower's occupants.

entries.name: Simulacrum
entries: The characters must fight Amath and her acolytes to get the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}. When they finally obtain it, fate deals them an unkind hand as {@creature Manshoon|WDH}'s simulacrum (see "{@creature Manshoon|WDH}" in appendix B) arrives by way of the teleportation circle in {@area O5|1b2}. If the characters had the opportunity and the foresight to destroy the circle prior to obtaining the stone, the simulacrum instead must travel to Yellowspire on foot, giving the characters ample time to get away before it arrives as long as they leave within 1 hour after obtaining the stone. The simulacrum tirelessly pursues the stone, and characters who flee would do themselves well not to leave tracks in the snow.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: If a character becomes attuned to the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}, it reveals the location of the Vault of Dragons, under the Brandath family mausoleum in the City of the Dead, and the three keys needed to enter it. When the characters are ready to visit the mausoleum, proceed with encounter 4, "Mausoleum."

entries.name: Encounter 8: Courthouse
entries: People who are arrested by the City Watch are brought to a courthouse and detained until a magister can pass judgment on them. Each courthouse has the following features:

items: Two {@creature guard||guards} stand outside each of the front and back doors (leading to areas H1 and H6) at all hours.
Rooms have 10-foot-high ceilings, with 8-foot-high passages and 7-foot-high doorways connecting them.
Windows are fitted with iron bars that require a successful DC 30 Strength (Athletics) check to bend.
Doors are made of iron-bound oak and unlocked.
All areas are brightly lit by {@spell continual flame} spells cast on wall sconces.
Cisterns on the roof collect rainwater, which is funneled by pipes down to the showers ({@area H7|1cf}).

entries.name: Areas of the Courthouse
entries: The following locations are keyed to map 4.6.

entries.name: H1. Upstairs Waiting Room
entries: This room has the following features:

items: Two {@creature guard||guards} stand outside the doors to the records rooms ({@area H2|1ca}) at all hours. Behind a desk sits a court clerk ({@creature commoner}). Uncomfortable wood benches line the walls. A copper plaque mounted above each bench says, in Common, "Please have a seat. Someone will be with you shortly."
Two privies are situated in a corner by the entrance.

entries.name: Clerk
entries: The clerk asks visitors what their business is and either directs them to the appropriate area of the courthouse or instructs them to wait. The clerk holds a key to the records rooms ({@area H2|1ca}).

entries.name: H2. Records Rooms
entries: The doors to these rooms are locked. Inside, shelves lining every available inch of wall space hold boxes of papers dated by month and year. These papers are records of court proceedings and depositions.

entries.name: H3. Clerks' Office
entries: Two desks pushed together in the middle of the room hold quills, ink, and sheets of paper. Two court clerks ({@creature commoner||commoners}) work here, supporting the magister on duty. Each clerk holds a key to the records rooms ({@area H2|1ca}).

entries.name: H4. Magister's Office
entries: This grand office contains several plush armchairs and a large walnut desk. The seal of Waterdeep is emblazoned on the wood floor.
When not overseeing a trial, a magister on duty at the courthouse reviews cases and holds meetings here. If a magister is here, so is a {@creature knight} who serves as a bodyguard.

entries.name: H5. Courtroom
entries: This room has the following features:

items: Two {@creature guard||guards} are stationed here at all times.
If court is in session, the magister is here along with a bodyguard (see {@area H4|1cc}) and anyone else pertinent to the case being tried.
A magister's cloth-draped desk faces a defendant's box and three rows of pews.

Hanging on the west wall are tasseled banners depicting the coats of arms of the City of Waterdeep, the Waterdeep City Watch, and the Waterdeep City Guard, as well as the seal of the Lords of Waterdeep and the symbol of Tyr, god of justice.

entries.name: H6. Downstairs Waiting Room
entries: Nobles scheduled to testify in court and those waiting to visit prisoners are held here. The room contains the following features:

items: Two {@creature guard||guards} are on duty in this room at all times.
Mismatched couches line the walls.
Old broadsheets rest in loose piles atop end tables.

entries.name: H7. Showers
entries: Dirty prisoners are stripped of their clothing and washed here before they are locked in cells. Protruding from the walls are iron nozzles that spew cold water when a chain next to the door is pulled. Drains in the stone-tiled floor keep the room from flooding.

entries.name: H8. Cell Block
entries: Two {@creature guard||guards} are stationed in this hall at all times.

entries.name: Locked Cells
entries: Five cells are spaced along this hall. The door to each cell is locked from the outside, and the guards stationed here hold the keys. A door's lock can't be picked from inside the cell.

entries.name: H9. Watch Wagon
entries: This room contains the following features:

items: Two {@creature veteran||veterans}, members of the City Watch, are here at all times.
An armored carriage stands behind a pair of steel doors secured by an iron bar.

entries.name: Armored Carriage
entries: Two horses are needed to pull the carriage, which can hold up to eight Medium prisoners at a time. The back door to the carriage is secured with chains and two padlocks. Each veteran on duty has a key that opens one of the padlocks.

entries.name: Barred Outer Doors
entries: It takes two people to lift the bar that obstructs the doors to the outside. A successful DC 21 Strength (Athletics) check enables one person to do it alone.

entries.name: Courthouse: Summer
entries: After obtaining the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}, the characters are arrested by the City Watch soon after they emerge from the sewers.

entries.name: Under Arrest
entries: The arresting force consists of twelve {@creature veteran||veterans}, a Watch {@creature sergeant|WDH} and eleven constables. They demand that the characters surrender their weapons and come along quietly. For guidance on how to handle character arrests, see "Breaking the Law,".

The characters are charged with disturbing the peace, a minor offense that carries a fine and results in an edict. The charge stems from their conduct in encounter 3, "Street Chase." Depending on how they comported themselves in previous encounters, the characters might be charged with additional crimes against the city or its citizens, possibly including brandishing weapons without due cause, robbery, assaulting a citizen, or murder. If they resist arrest, they are charged with hampering justice. See the Code Legal handout in appendix C for the penalties associated with such crimes.

Characters who give up their visible weapons without a fuss aren't searched, but those who give the Watch a hard time are searched for hidden weapons (and stripped of anything that could potentially cause harm). A character can conceal a Tiny object from the Watch with a successful DC 12 Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check. If the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} is found during a search, the Watch {@creature sergeant|WDH} inspects it, concludes that it's nothing of consequence, and returns it to its owner.

entries.name: Dock Ward Courthouse
entries: Arrested characters are brought to a courthouse in the Dock Ward and confined to cells ({@area H8|1d0}) until their trial. Any items taken from them during their arrest are entrusted to the front desk clerk ({@area H1|1c8}) pending the trial's outcome. A character can take a short rest while incarcerated and use that time to attune to the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}. After {@dice 1d6} hours, word comes down that the magister is prepared to hear the characters' testimony, whereupon the guards in {@area H8|1d0} unlock the characters' cells and escort them to the courtroom ({@area H5|1cd}), where the magister is waiting.

entries.name: False Captain
entries: If Lord Cassalanter's {@creature doppelganger} valet is still at large, it kills a Watch captain and uses the victim's uniform to impersonate another Watch captain the characters have met before. Then, in the guise of Hyustus Staget (see "The Watch Arrives"), the doppelganger kills the guards in {@area H8|1d0} with its bare hands and uses their keys to open the characters' cells. "Hyustus" warns them that the magister is corrupt and suggests they flee the city before they're sentenced to death. "Hyustus" offers to deliver messages or items of import on their behalf while they make good their escape. The doppelganger is hoping that the characters will entrust the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} to it for safekeeping. Failing that, it hopes to wrest the stone from them during the chaos of the jailbreak.

If the characters refuse to play along, the doppelganger cries out in alarm, bringing the full weight of the courthouse garrison (ten {@creature guard||guards} and two {@creature veteran||veterans}) down upon the characters, whom "Hyustus" accuses of beating the cell block guards to death. These reinforcements have no reason to believe that Captain Staget isn't who he appears to be, and they side with him in any conflict.

If the doppelganger obtains the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}, it promptly delivers it to {@creature Victoro Cassalanter|WDH}. If the characters extricate themselves from the mess they're in, they can retrieve the stone from Cassalanter Villa (see chapter 6).

entries.name: Meeting with the Magister
entries: The presiding magister is Umbero Zastro, a handsome, eloquent, and fair-minded half-elf in his thirties. He's known for his finely-honed sense of poetic justice and for meting out unconventional punishments.
{@creature Magister Umbero Zastro|wdh} has the statistics of a {@creature noble}, with these changes:

items: He is lawful neutral.
He is unarmed, unarmored (AC 11), and worth 0 XP.

Il possède ces caractéristiques raciales : Il a un avantage sur les jets de sauvegarde contre l'être {@condition charmed}, et la magie ne peut pas l'endormir. Il a une vision dans le noir jusqu'à une portée de 60 pieds. Il parle le commun et l'elfique.

entries: The magister has already heard the testimony of the arresting officers, as well as that of any eyewitnesses. The characters are given an hour to plead their case while he asks questions. A character who tries to deceive Zastro must make a Charisma (Deception) check contested by the magister's Wisdom (Insight) check. A character who loses this contest is found guilty of hampering justice, locked up for a tenday, and fined 200 gp, on top of any other punishments meted out for crimes committed against the city and its citizenry. Those who can't or won't pay the fine are sentenced to hard labor for a year in Amendsfarm, a City Guard-run labor camp among the farms of Undercliff.

If the characters committed one or more crimes, they are judged guilty and punished accordingly (see the Code Legal handout in appendix C). A character who pleads for leniency and succeeds on a DC 14 Charisma (Persuasion) check receives an alternate punishment for crimes that don't carry punishments of death or exile. This check is made with advantage if the character has renown in a respectable faction, such as Force Grey (the Gray Hands), the Emerald Enclave, the Harpers, the Lords' Alliance, or the Order of the Gauntlet. Alternate punishments for lesser crimes include the following:

items: The character must make beds and clean bedsheets at local orphanages for a tenday, under guard supervision.
The character must report to Morana Huldark, a dwarf member of the Guild of Watermen, and scrape barnacles off the docks for a tenday under her close supervision.
The character must spend the next month delivering 30-pound casks of drinking water to the guards stationed atop the city walls.

For a tenday, the character must stand on a particular street corner every afternoon from highsun to dusk and, like a broadcrier, shout out the crimes of which he or she has been found guilty while accepting the scoldings and verbal lashings of the citizenry.

entries: Characters who are tricked into acting in accordance with the wishes of the doppelganger can be forgiven for crimes committed during the jailbreak, but only if the doppelganger is apprehended or killed. (It reverts to its true form when it dies.) {@spell Speak with dead} spells can be cast on the cell block guards slain by the doppelganger to obtain testimony that clears the characters of the guards' murder.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: If a character becomes attuned to the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}, it reveals the location of the Vault of Dragons, beneath an old tower in the Sea Ward, and the three keys needed to enter it. When the characters are ready to visit the location, proceed with encounter 7, "Old Tower."

entries.name: Courthouse: Autumn
entries: The characters have learned that Fenerus Stormcastle is in the custody of the City Watch at a courthouse in the Castle Ward. If they try to speak with him, they are met by the clerk at the front desk, who informs them that they must schedule a meeting with the magister first, because visitors need her written permission to see him. The clerk says the meeting with the magister can happen no sooner than highsun on the following day but can be persuaded to move up the time for a bribe of 10 gp or more.
There are alternatives to speaking with the magister, if the characters have sufficient renown in a politically influential faction-or a talent for deception:

items: A character who has at least 4 renown in the Harpers can convince {@creature Mirt|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) to use his authority as a Lord of Waterdeep to secure Fenerus's release. {@creature Mirt|WDH} has personally lost coin to the Blood Hawk Posse, so helping Fenerus squirm out of jail stings him deeply.

A character who has at least 4 renown in the Lords' Alliance can arrange a meeting with {@creature Laeral Silverhand|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) at Piergeiron's Palace and convince her to give Fenerus what he wants in exchange for information on the stone's whereabouts. The safe return of Neverember's cache of dragons is more important to her than the fate of one brigand.

The characters can purposely get themselves arrested in the Castle Ward. Even a minor crime can result in a brief period of incarceration until the magister has time to render judgment. In the meantime, characters can try to speak to Fenerus.

The characters can try to infiltrate the courthouse using mundane disguises or magic. Impersonating an official or using magic to influence one is a crime (see the Code Legal handout in appendix C), so they must be stealthy or skilled at deception.

items.name: Meeting with the Magister
entries: The courthouse magister is {@creature Hester Barch|WDH} (LG female Turami human {@creature acolyte} with Insight +4), a petite woman in her seventies. Magister Barch is slow to anger and fond of sharing lengthy educational anecdotes and parables. Unknown to all but her closest aides, the magister has the innate psionic ability to cast the {@spell detect thoughts} spell without somatic or material components. After using it once, the magister must finish a short or long rest before she can cast the spell again. Wisdom is her spellcasting ability (spell save DC 12).

The magister is disinclined to agree to any request for a private meeting with Fenerus, on the grounds that he's a shady, unrepentant person and a flight risk. The conditions under which she will permit a meeting are as follows:

items: A character who has at least 3 renown in the Harpers or the Lords' Alliance, or a character who belongs to a Waterdavian noble family, makes a good argument and succeeds on a DC 15 Charisma (Persuasion) check.

A character who is impersonating a noble or an official makes a good argument and succeeds on a DC 15 Charisma (Deception) check. If the check fails, Magister Barch sees through the ruse and uses her {@spell detect thoughts} spell to verify that the character is in fact disguised as a noble or an official-a crime that carries a punishment of flogging followed by imprisonment for up to a tenday, plus a fine of up to 500 gp.
A character tells the magister about the hidden cache of dragons and Fenerus's role in finding it.

items.name: Talking to Fenerus
entries: Fenerus Stormcastle (N male Tethyrian {@creature bandit captain}) is confined to a cell in {@area H8|1d0}, waiting to stand trial. He is charged with multiple counts of theft (highway banditry) and assaults against Waterdavian citizens. Fenerus knew it was only a matter of time until someone tipped off the City Watch; he suspects that another member of the Blood Hawk Posse gave him up. The timing is unfortunate for him, since he was planning to earn a small fortune by turning over the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} to his Luskanite contact. Now, he plans to use the stone to escape imprisonment and wipe his criminal record clean.

If the characters can get close enough to speak with him, Fenerus refuses to divulge the stone's location until he is released and granted immunity for his past crimes. He knows that the presiding magister or a Lord of Waterdeep has the authority to give him what he wants.

The only condition under which Magister Barch will consider acquiescing to Fenerus's demands is if the characters convince her that such a decision is good for Waterdeep. To accomplish that, they either must use magic to beguile her (which is a crime and likely to result in the caster's arrest once the effect wears off), or they must tell her about the Vault of Dragons and the stolen gold. In either case, she insists on trying something before letting him off the hook: after taking a short rest, she has Fenerus brought to her courtroom and questions him about the stone. Surreptitiously, she uses her {@spell detect thoughts} spell to scan his surface thoughts in an attempt to discern the stone's location. Given that the stone is foremost in Fenerus's mind, Magistrate Barch learns where it is hidden, shares the information with the characters, and returns Fenerus to his cell.

items.name: Where's the Stone?
entries: Fenerus hid the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} on the top floor of an old tower in the Dock Ward-a tower warded against all forms of magic. If he is freed, he offers to lead the characters to the tower or provides directions so they can find it on their own.

items.name: Next Encounter
entries: If the characters learn where Fenerus hid the stone and go after it, proceed with encounter 7, "Old Tower."

entries.name: Encounter 9: Cellar Complex
entries: Cellars and sewer tunnels intersect to create small dungeons under Waterdeep. These complexes have the following features:

items: Ceilings and doorways are 7 feet high.
There are no light sources.

entries.name: Areas of the Cellar Complex
entries: The following locations are keyed to map 4.7. The complex has three distinct sections: the sewer tunnels (areas B1-B3), the southern cellars (areas B4-B9), and the northern cellars (areas B10-B11).

entries.name: B1. Sewer Access
entries: This chamber has stone steps and a locked, iron-bound wooden door with a sign mounted on it that reads, in Common, "SEWER ACCESS: AUTHORIZED CITY OFFICIALS ONLY." The door to {@area B2|1e3} is locked. The lock can be picked by a character who makes a successful DC 17 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, or the door can be forced open with a successful DC 20 Strength (Athletics) check. City Watch captains hold keys to sewer access points that correspond with their assigned wards.

entries.name: B2. Sewers
entries: Fresh sewage flows along a trough that runs parallel to a stone walkway. The sewage is 3 feet deep. Any creature immersed in it for 1 minute must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or become infected with {@disease sewer plague} (see "Diseases" in chapter 8 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|dmg}).
Where the tunnel branches, a stone bridge spans the sewage pouring out of an eastern artery. There's no walkway in this arterial passage that leads to areas B3 and B4.

entries.name: B3. Secret Doors
entries: Secret doors blend with the surrounding stonework on opposite sides of this sewer tunnel. One door opens into {@area B7|1e8}, the other into {@area B10|1f0}. Characters who have a passive Perception score of 15 or higher spot both secret doors as they pass by. Otherwise, finding a secret door requires a search of the wall and a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check. The secret doors are set high enough that opening them doesn't cause sewage to flow into adjoining areas.

entries.name: B4. Rusty Iron Door
entries: A door made of rusted iron is set into the wall above a dry, 1-foot-wide stone ledge. The door's lock corroded long ago, and the door squeals loudly on rusty hinges when opened.

entries.name: B5. Arrow Slits
entries: A brick wall with arrow slits was added to this room at some point. The arrow slits are designed to allow archers to fire at intruders who come through the door at {@area B4|1e5}. The arrow slits provide three-quarters cover.

entries.name: B6. Storage Room
entries: An unlocked wooden door closes off this empty room.

entries.name: B7. Rubble-Filled Cellar
entries: A wall has collapsed, creating a larger space out of two smaller rooms. The air is heavy with dust, and the floor is strewn with rubble, refuse, and rat droppings.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: The secret door to {@area B3|1e4} is easily spotted from this side (no check required).

entries.name: B8. Sunken Cellar
entries: This sunken cellar has these features:

items: An unlocked iron door is set into the east wall.
A crumbling stone staircase against the south wall climbs up to a landing, where a wooden door is held shut with a chain and a padlock.

entries.name: Iron Door
entries: The door opens into a small, empty storage room with hooks hanging from the ceiling.

entries.name: Stairs Up
entries: The lock can be picked with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check made using thieves' tools, or the door can be forced open with a successful DC 20 Strength (Athletics) check. It opens into an alley behind a boarded-up tenement.

entries.name: B9. Rat-Infested Cellar
entries: These rooms are situated below a hostel ({@chance 75|75 percent chance}) or an orphanage ({@chance 25|25 percent chance}). Harmless rats crawl about, minding their own business.

entries.name: B9a
entries: Stone stairs climb 10 feet to a wooden door that opens into a street or alley. Crates and barrels stacked at the bottom of the stairs hold edible foodstuffs, but nothing else of value.

entries.name: B9b
entries: A plain wooden door opens into a room containing dusty furnishings in storage. The furniture includes a scratched wooden desk, several wobbly chairs, a coat rack, two small tables, and an empty wooden trunk. There's a {@chance 25|25 percent chance} that one piece of furniture (determined randomly) is a {@creature mimic} that usually feeds on rats but never passes up a bigger meal.

entries.name: B10. Old Tavern Cellar
entries: This spacious, empty cellar has the following features:

items: Stone pillars and arches support the ceiling.
Mismatched stonework on either side of a half-demolished wall indicates that this area was once two separate chambers.
Stone stairs climb to a bricked-up doorway. (The door once led to an alley behind an old tavern.)

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: The secret door to {@area B3|1e4} is easily spotted from this side (no check required).

entries.name: B11. Back Cellars
entries: These rooms are extensions of {@area B10|1f0}.

entries.name: B11a
entries: This room used to be a wine cellar. Its walls are lined with piles of rotting wood (storage racks) and broken bottles.

entries.name: B11b
entries: Once a cold storage room and root cellar, this empty chamber is choked with dust and cobwebs.

entries.name: Cellar Complex: Spring
entries: The characters have learned that a halfling necromancer named {@creature Losser Mirklav|wdh} took the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}. He lives in a cellar complex under a powdered wig shop in the Trades Ward. The shop, Dandymops, is closed and locked with an iron gate. The lock can be picked by a character who makes a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, or the gate can be forced open with a successful DC 25 Strength (Athletics) check. Since the shop is in a highly visible location, an attempt to break into it is 75 percent likely to be noticed by someone who alerts the City Watch. Two {@creature veteran||veterans} of the City Watch arrive in {@dice 1d10} minutes to investigate the shop and talk to witnesses.

{@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s {@creature gazer|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) doesn't follow characters into the shop. It remains outside and waits for {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild forces to arrive. If the characters destroyed the gazer in an earlier encounter, another one arrives with the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild forces.

entries.name: Dungeon Entrance
entries: {@area B1|1e2|u} is the basement of the wig shop and the characters' point of entry into the cellar complex.

entries.name: Misty Sewers
entries: The dense fog from outside settles in the sewers, and areas B2, B3, and B4 are lightly obscured.

entries.name: Necromancer
entries: {@creature Losser Mirklav|wdh} is a lightfoot halfling {@creature mage}, with these changes:

items: He is chaotic evil and has 31 ({@dice 9d6}) hit points.

He has these racial traits: He is Small, and his walking speed is 25 feet. He can move through the space of a Medium or larger creature. He has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}. He speaks Common and Halfling.
He has the {@spell animate dead} and {@spell blight} spells prepared, instead of {@spell counterspell} and {@spell greater invisibility}. All his spell slots are currently expended.

entries: Losser carries a spellbook bound in stitched flesh that contains all his prepared spells. He also has a key to the padlocked door in {@area B8|1ea} and {@dice 4d10} gp in a pouch made of elf skin and cinched with a rope made of woven dwarf hair.
Losser has made several changes to the complex:

items: {@area B6|1e7|u} contains three beds-two sized for Losser's human apprentices and a smaller bed sized for him.
{@area B10|1f0|u} contains twelve {@creature skeleton||skeletons} that attack anyone other than Losser and his apprentices.
{@area B11|1f2|u} contains piles of human bones stolen from the City of the Dead. Losser hasn't gotten around to animating them yet.

entries.name: Where's the Stone?
entries: Before the characters reach Losser, kenku members of the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild break down the door leading into the cellar complex via {@area B8|1ea} and confront the necromancer. The characters find Losser cowering in one corner of {@area B7|1e8}. Two {@creature skeleton||skeletons} stand between him and three {@creature kenku}. The kenku aim to kill the halfling. Lying on the floor around them are four dead kenku and the remains of two destroyed (and previously animated) skeletons.

If the characters demand the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}, Losser tells them the truth: he surrendered it to the kenku, two of which fled south with it. In {@area B8|1ea}, the characters see one {@creature kenku} standing over the bodies of Losser's murdered human apprentices, Retchyn and Kreela. This kenku is joined by {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s {@creature gazer|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}). The kenku and the gazer try to hold off the characters for as long as possible, buying time for a second kenku to flee with the Stone of Golorr.
If the characters pursue the stone and leave Losser alive, he eventually slips away and retreats to {@area B11|1f2}.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: Once the characters defeat {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s forces in the cellar, they can chase after the fleeing kenku that has the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} in its clutches. Proceed with encounter 3, "Street Chase."

entries.name: Cellar Complex: Summer
entries: The characters are hot on the trail of three street urchins as the children scamper into the sewers under the Dock Ward.

entries.name: Sickening Smell
entries: The summer heat makes the sewer smell worse than usual, and characters become {@condition poisoned} by the stench unless they cover their noses with perfumed scarves. The effect lasts until they leave the sewers. The street urchins and other creatures that live in the sewers are accustomed to the smell and aren't {@condition poisoned} in this way.

entries.name: Search for the Urchins
entries: The characters approach the cellar complex from the east, eventually coming upon an iron door in the side of the sewer tunnel ({@area B4|1e5}).

The street urchins took the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} to {@area B7|1e8} (which serves as their clubhouse), entering the room through a secret door ({@area B3|1e4}). The eldest child, {@creature Nat|WDH}, attuned to the stone, but contact with the aboleth so terrified her that she dropped it, screamed, and ran away. The boys were panicked by her reaction and fled as well, leaving the stone in {@area B7|1e8}. If the characters open the door at {@area B4|1e5}, they startle the children on the other side, causing them to scream at the top of their lungs.
Communicating through the other children, {@creature Nat|WDH} tells the characters where she dropped the stone and warns them that it's "alive." Neither she nor the boys are eager to see it again.

entries.name: Chair Today, Gone Tomorrow
entries: If the characters head to {@area B7|1e8}, they see the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} underneath a wooden rocking chair. If the street urchins are present, one of them asks, "Where'd that rocking chair come from?"
The rocking chair is the {@creature mimic} from {@area B9b|1ef}. It heard the urchins' screams and investigated, hoping to snare an easy meal. It attacks anyone who harms it or reaches for the stone.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: Once the characters obtain the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}, they can leave the cellar complex. Proceed with encounter 8, "Courthouse."

entries.name: Cellar Complex: Autumn
entries: The characters have been encouraged to explore a {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild hideout under the Southern Ward. They enter the location through {@area B1|1e2}. The {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild Roster table provides a summary of the forces stationed throughout the complex. The sections that follow describe some of the hideout's features.

entries.caption: Xanathar Guild Roster
rows: 1 {@creature Half-Ogre (Ogrillon)||half-ogre} that became {@condition poisoned} after drinking six casks of cheap wine

3 {@creature duergar} and 1 {@creature gazer|vgm} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) standing guard while {@creature Thorvin Twinbeard|wdh} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) works on a mechanical beholder (see "Mechanical Beholder" below)
Korgstrod Uxgulm, the {@creature duergar} leader (40 hit points), seated in a stone chair and attended by 3 {@creature kobold||kobolds} (see "Stone of Deception" below)
1 {@creature gibbering mouther} guarding a treasure chest in {@area B11b|1f4} (see "Treasure Chest" below)

entries.name: Mechanical Beholder
entries: A mechanical beholder built for the Day of Wonders parade lies on its side in {@area B7|1e8}. {@creature Xanathar|WDH} wants this mechanical version of itself to hover over the crowd, reminding the Lords of Waterdeep of the beholder's superiority, but no one can figure out how to make it fly. A character can use an action to try to activate the machine, doing so with a successful DC 10 Intelligence check. The activated beholder shoots dazzling lights from its eyestalks for 1 minute and then stops working.

If combat breaks out in the cellar complex, {@creature Thorvin Twinbeard|wdh} flees up the stairs in {@area B8|1ea} and uses a key to unlock the door leading outside. He has no loyalty to the other creatures stationed here.

entries.name: Stone of Deception
entries: Korgstrod Uxgulm, the duergar leader, has what he believes to be the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}. He found it during a search of Fenerus's house in the Trades Ward. This stone is a clever imitation. It's gray and ovoid with streaks of black, but has no magical powers. Korgstrod has been unable to attune to it and assumes he's unworthy of it, not that the stone is fake.

Korgstrod plans to deliver the stone to {@creature Xanathar|WDH} in due time and won't willingly part with it before then. He uses a whip to flog his kobold lackeys and keep them in line. The cowardly kobolds flee into the sewers if Korgstrod is attacked and cower in his presence otherwise.

entries.name: Treasure Chest
entries: An old, locked chest in the back of {@area B11b|1f4} can be opened by someone who makes a successful DC 13 Dexterity check using thieves' tools. The chest contains 277 cp, 135 sp, a spherical gold beholder pendant with tiny gems for eyes (worth 250 gp), and a {@item spell scroll} of {@spell darkvision}.

entries.name: Next Encounter
entries: Whether they find the fake stone or not, characters have little recourse but to consult with "Laeral" at the Seven Masks Theater in the Dock Ward. If they go there, proceed with encounter 6, "Theater."

entries.name: Encounter 10: Converted Windmill
entries: This crumbling, two-story stone building was a windmill long before the city rose up around it. The following features apply unless an area description or encounter states otherwise:

items: Rooms have 15-foot-high ceilings, with 10-foot-high passages and 7-foot-high doorways connecting them.
Doors are wooden, closed, and unlocked.
The walls are covered with graffiti, and the stone floors are strewn with garbage and detritus. Windows are empty lead frames without glass.
There are no light sources.

entries.name: Areas of the Converted Windmill
entries: The following locations are keyed to map 4.8.

entries.name: W1. Stone Staircase
entries: A curved set of stone stairs climbs 20 feet to the upper level. The stairs are covered with bird droppings, broken roof shingles, mud, and mold.

entries.name: W2. Squatters
entries: During the spring, summer, and winter, each of these rooms is home to {@dice 1d6 + 1} squatters ({@creature commoner||commoners}) who have made dens for themselves out of old furnishings and things salvaged from garbage piles. The squatters aren't looking for trouble.

For some food or coin, a squatter can direct or lead characters to the locked apartment on the upper level ({@area W7|20d}) and describe the apartment's inhabitants. A character can also secure a squatter's cooperation with a successful DC 10 Charisma (Intimidation) check.

entries.name: W3. Privy
entries: Beyond the door is nothing more than a hole in the floor from which rises a terrible stench.

entries.name: W4. Weak Ceiling/Floor
entries: Area {@b W4a} is directly underneath area {@b W4b}. The floor of the upper chamber collapses under the weight of the first Small or larger creature to walk across it. A character who has the Stonecunning trait or proficiency with mason's tools can tell that the floor is unsafe to walk on.

Any creature standing on the floor of area W4b when it collapses falls 20 feet, landing in area W4a. Any creature in area W4a when the ceiling falls in must make a DC 11 Dexterity saving throw, taking 4 ({@dice 1d8}) bludgeoning damage from falling debris on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: W5. Ancient Millstone
entries: An ancient millstone lies under a jumble of debris that includes machinery and pieces of the collapsed roof. Dust and cobwebs cover everything.

entries.name: W6. Pigeon Roosts
entries: Large sections of the roof have caved in above these rooms, leaving holes through which birds and precipitation can enter. The floors are littered with broken shingles, bird droppings, wrecked furnishings, and other detritus, and scores of pigeons roost in the moldy rafters.

entries.name: W7. Secure Apartment
entries: The north door to this room has been fitted with a shiny new lock that can be picked with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves' tools. The door can also be unlocked from inside the room, or forced open with a successful DC 20 Strength (Athletics) check.
This apartment is in good repair and contains the following features:

items: A wood-framed, king-sized bed with clean mattresses stands against one wall. (Next to the bed, an unlocked door in the west wall leads to {@area W8|20e}.)
The window was recently repaired and quietly swings open on oiled iron hinges.
Across from the window, against the wall, stands a wooden armoire.

entries: The armoire holds four clean sets of clothes, two gray cloaks, a heavy crossbow, and a wooden case containing twenty crossbow bolts.

entries.name: W8. Back Room
entries: The section of conical roof directly above this chamber has mostly collapsed, filling the room with rubble. There's just enough space to open the door.

entries.name: Converted Windmill: Spring
entries: The key that the characters found in the mausoleum leads them to an old windmill in the Southern Ward. Volkarr Kibbens and Urlaster Ghann (NE male Illuskan human {@creature commoner||commoners}) are hiding out in a secure apartment on the upper floor ({@area W7|20d}). In combat, they wield shovels that deal damage as clubs. Each carries {@dice 3d6} gp in a pouch.

Volkarr and Urlaster were recently hired by {@creature Losser Mirklav|wdh}, a halfling necromancer, to help him break into mausoleums in the City of the Dead. They undertook the job because the pay was good, but they have no loyalty to the necromancer. If the characters confront them, Volkarr and Urlaster attack, but they surrender quickly if overwhelmed and share the following information in exchange for their lives and freedom:

items: {@creature Losser Mirklav|wdh} and his two human apprentices, Retchyn and Kreela, live in a cellar complex under the Trades Ward. The way to their lair is through Retchyn's powdered wig shop, which is called Dandymops.
Losser is stealing bones from the City of the Dead to create an army of animated skeletons. (Neither Volkarr nor Urlaster knows why.)
